questions.text: What are the two terminal branches of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Musculocutaneous and median The lateral cord divides into the musculocutaneous and median nerves. The posterior cord terminates into the axillary and radial nerves . The medial cord divides into the ulnar and median nerves.

Highyeild:

Brachial plexus is formed by confluence ventral of nerve roots from C5 to T1. Modes of injury either a stab wound or severe traction caused by a fall on the side of neck or the shoulder. Traction injuries are generally classified as supraclavicular, infraclavicular and combined. Supraclavicular lesions typically occurs in motor cycle accident as the cyclist collides with the ground and his neck and shoulder are wrenched apart (may be associated with subclavian artery injury). Infraclavicular lesions are usually associated with fractures or dislocations of the shoulder. & axillary artery injury HYP Splint used for brachial injury is aeroplane splint.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Musculocutaneous nerve is derived from the lateral cord and the axillary nerve is derived from the posterior cord Option: C. Median nerve is derived from the mainly medial cord and axillary nerve is derived from the posterior cord Option: D. Medial cord divides into the ulnar and median nerves

questions.text: What neurovascular structure is at greatest risk when creating a proximal anterolateral elbow arthroscopy portal?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radial nerve The radial nerve is 4 to 7 mm from the anterolateral portal, which is placed 1 cm anterior and 3 cm proximal to the lateral epicondyle . The posterior interosseous nerve can lie 1 to 14 mm from the portal site.

Highyeild:

Nerve Supply 1. Above elbow 2. Below elbow a. Above spiral groove: i. Triceps (long, medial head) ii. Posterior cutaneous nerve of arm b. In spiral groove: Sensory i. Posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm ii. Lateral cutaneous nerve of arm iii. Anconeus iv. Triceps (medial & lateral heads) c. Between spiral groove & lateral epicondyle i.. Brachialis ii.Brachioradialis iii. Extensor Carpi Radialis longus a.Posterior interosseous remaining Muscles Nerve supply i. Abductor pollicis longus ii. Extensor pollicis Longus & brevis iii. Extensor indicis iv. Supinator iv. Extensor digitorum vi. Extensor digit, minimi vii. Extensor carpi ulnaris viii.Extensor carpi radialis brevis • Autonomous zone for radial nerve is dorsum of 1st web space Sensory loss in the area supplied by the posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm. Wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost (ie. wrist, thumb & finger drop). Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN) Injury It is prone to be injured in injury & operations of radial head - neck or fractures like monteggia There is no sensory deficit, it is a pure motor nerve. Wrist extension is preserved (i.e. no wrist drop) due to spared extensor carpi radialis longus Presents with loss of extension of metacarpophalangeal (MP) joints i.e. thumb & finger drop Type of Radial Nerve Lesion Very high (i.e. above spiral groove) Total palsy i.e. Elbow, wrist, thumb & finger extension is lost Loss of sensation High (i.e. between spiral groove & lateral epicondyle) Elbow extension spared Lost: Wrist, thumb, finger extension & sensation Low Elbow & Wrist extension spared Lost: thumb, finger extension & sensa

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve is more prone to damage in the distal anterolateral portal and direct lateral portal Option: C. Posterior interosseous nerve is more to damage in the distal anterolateral approach Option: D. Median nerve is prone to damage in anteromedial an approach

questions.text: Injury to which of the following nerves results in winging of the scapula?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Long thoracic nerve The long thoracic nerve is derived from the ventral rami of C5, C6 and C7 . It runs downward, passing either in front of or behind the middle scalene muscle. It then descends onto the anterior surface of the serratus anterior muscle, giving branches to supply it.

Highyeild:

Long Thoracic Nerve: The long thoracic nerve is usually formed by roots from the fifth to the seventh cervical rami, although the last ramus may be absent. Clinical abnormality Winging of the scapula: There is prominence of vertebral borders and inferior angle of scapula when the patient attempt to exert forward pushing movements with hands. It is best demonstrated by asking the patient to push against resistance with the arm extended at the elbow and flexed to 90° At the shoulder serratus anterior muscle is affected. Deformity: Inability to flex the arm above the shoulder level anteriorly & restriction of active abduction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Axillary nerve mainly supplies the deltoid and teres minor muscle Option: B. Suprascapular nerve supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscle Option: C. Medial pectoral nerve supplies the pectoralis minor muscle

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly injured in humeral shaft fractures?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radial nerve Approximately 8% of humeral shaft fractures are associated with a radial nerve palsy

Highyeild:

Approximately 8% of humeral shaft fractures are associated with radial nerve palsy. This occurs most commonly with middle and distal third fractures. Classically, the Holstein–Lewis fracture is associated with this complication. This is a fracture of the distal third of the humerus, where the radial nerve is caught between the bone ends when the fracture is reduced.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B: Approximately 8% of humeral shaft fractures are associated with a radial nerve palsy, not musculocutaneous nerve Option: C. Approximately 8% of humeral shaft fractures are associated with a radial nerve palsy, not median nerve Option: D. Approximately 8% of humeral shaft fractures are associated with a radial nerve palsy, not ulnar nerve

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has sustained a minimally displaced spiral fracture at the junction of the middle and distal thirds of the humeral shaft. He has extensive bruising and swelling of the upper arm, but no open wound is present. He has a loss of sensation over the first web space dorsally and is unable to extend his wrist or fingers. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A hanging plaster cast In the vast majority of cases (90–100%), the radial nerve injury is a neuropraxia hence in this case we observe the nerve and treat the fracture using a hanging plaster cast

Highyeild:

In the vast majority of cases (90–100%), the radial nerve injury is neuropraxia. Therefore, there is no need for urgent exploration so long as there is no indication of internal fixation of the fracture. Nerve conduction studies should be performed 3 weeks after the injury to establish a baseline. If no recovery occurs by 4 months after the injury, the nerve should be explored.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B & D In the vast majority of cases (90–100%), the radial nerve injury is a neuropraxia hence, in this case, we observe the nerve and treat the fracture using a hanging plaster cast, no manipulation is required

questions.text: Which of the following can distinguish between pre and postganglionic brachial plexus injuries?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intradermal histamine test Intradermal histamine test - Intradermal injection of histamine usually causes a triple response in the surrounding skin (central capillary dilatation, a weal and a surrounding ﬂare). If the ﬂare reaction persists in an anaesthetic area of skin, the lesion must be proximal to the posterior root ganglion, which means that it is probably a root avulsion. With a postganglionic lesion, the test will be negative because nerve continuity between the skin and the dorsal root ganglion is interrupted

Highyeild:

Preganglionic lesions (root avulsions) are irreparable: Postganglionic lesions may either recover (axonotmesis) or may be amenable to repair The histamine test is intriguing. Intradermal injection of histamine usually causes a triple response in the surrounding skin (central capillary dilatation, a weal and a surrounding ﬂare). If the ﬂare reaction persists in an anaesthetic area of skin, the lesion must be proximal to the posterior root ganglion, which means that it is probably a root avulsion. With a postganglionic lesion, the test will be negative because nerve continuity between the skin and the dorsal root ganglion is interrupted.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Angiography has no role in distinguishing between pre and postganglionic brachial plexus injuries. Option: B. Sonography has no role in distinguishing between pre and postganglionic brachial plexus injuries. Option: D. Radionuclide imaging has no role in distinguishing between pre and postganglionic brachial plexus injuries

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: With Klumpke palsy Horner’s syndrome may be present on the ipsilateral side

options.label: D
options.text: Histamine test differentiates pre and post-ganglionic region

questions.correct_answer: A. Preganglionic lesions have a better prognosis than postganglionic lesions
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Preganglionic lesions have a better prognosis than postganglionic lesions Postganglionic lesions have a better prognosis than preganglionic lesions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Erb's palsy is caused by injury of C5, C6 and (sometimes) C7 . (upper trunk). The abductors and external rotators of the shoulder and the supinators are paralysed Option: C. Klumpke's palsy is due to injury of C8 and T1 . The baby lies with the arm supinated and the elbow ﬂexed; there is a loss of intrinsic muscle power in the hand. Reﬂexes are absent and there may be a unilateral Horner's syndrome. Option: D. Intradermal Histamine test can distinguish between pre and postganglionic brachial plexus injuries

questions.text: Post Road Traffic Accident there is the inability to abduct the shoulder and flex elbow. This is due to the?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Upper trunk injury The inability to abduct the shoulder and flex the elbow is suggestive of Erb's palsy, Erb’s palsy is an upper trunk injury.

Highyeild:

The inability to abduct the shoulder and flex the elbow is suggestive of Erb's palsy Erb's palsy is caused by injury of C5, C6 and (sometimes) C7. (upper trunk) The abductors and external rotators of the shoulder and the supinators are paralysed. The arm is held to the side, internally rotated and pronated. There may also be loss of finger extension. The sensation cannot be tested in a baby.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Inability to abduct shoulder and flex elbow is suggestive of Erb's palsy , Not due to shoulder dislocation Option: B. No signs of medial cord injury Option: C. No sign of lateral cord injury

questions.text: All of the following features can be observed after the injury to the axillary nerve except?

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of sensation along the lateral side of the ARM

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of rounded contour off the shoulder

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Loss of overhead abduction Loss of overhead abduction is not lost in axillary nerve injury, initiation of abduction is lost.

Highyeild:

The patient complains of shoulder 'weakness', and the deltoid is wasted and loss of rounded contour off the shoulder ( Image A). Abduction can be initiated (by supraspinatus), but it cannot be maintained. Careful testing will reveal a small area of numbness over the deltoid (the 'sergeant's patch'). Supraspinatus alone is entirely capable of elevating the upper limb above head height ( Images B and C). A - Deltoid wasting in complete axillary nerve lesion. B C - Elevation is achievable by intact supraspinatus alone. Note that the elevation is in the scapular plane compared to the normal side.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Loss of sensation along the lateral side of ARM is due to axillary nerve injury, called regimen batch sign. Option: C. Loss of rounded contour off the shoulder is due to axillary nerve injury because of deltoid wasting. Option: D. Atrophy of the deltoid muscle is due to axillary nerve injury

questions.text: Mr Mohan presents with loss of sensation of the ring and little finger with wasting of hypothenar muscles. This is suggestive of injury to:

options.label: C
options.text: Ulnar before division into deep and superficial

Ulnar before division into deep and superficial The lesion is above the level of the hand as there is wasting of hypothenar muscles.

Highyeild:

The lesion is above the level of hand as there is wasting of hypothenar muscles In Hand ulnar nerve supplies Superficial branch Hypothenar Deep branch Adductor pollicis, All interossei Medial two lumbricals

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ulnar nerve Froment’s sign is done for Ulnar nerve Clinically, this compensation manifests as flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb (rather than adduction, as would occur with correct use of the adductor pollicis

questions.text: Loss of sensation in lateral 3and1/2 and finger, test to determine all except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Finkelstein test Finkelstein test Tenderness at the tip of the radial styloid suggests de Quervain's disease. Sensory symptoms can often be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve ( Tinel's sign ) (Tendovaginitis of the combined sheath for extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus). By holding the wrist fully flexed for less than 60 seconds ( Phalen's test ). Tenderness at the tip of the radial styloid suggests de Quervain's disease This diagnosis can be confirmed by Finkelstein's test.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Phalen test – used to detect median nerve compressive neuropathy , By holding the wrist fully flexed for less than 60 seconds Option: C. Tinel sign – used to assess nerve injury, Sensory symptoms can often be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve Option: D. Tourniquet test - used to assess nerve injury

questions.text: The most common physical findings in a patient with median nerve compression at the wrist (carpal tunnel syndrome) are:

options.label: A
options.text: Diminished two-point discrimination and dryness of the index and long fingers

options.label: B
options.text: Atrophy of the abductor pollicis brevis and opponens pollicis

options.label: C
options.text: A positive percussion test at the wrist and a positive wrist flexion test produced paresthesia at the thumb, index, and long fingers

options.label: D
options.text: A weak grip in addition to hand cramping and difficulty writing

questions.correct_answer: C. A positive percussion test at the wrist and a positive wrist flexion test produced paresthesia at the thumb, index, and long fingers
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A positive percussion test at the wrist and a positive wrist flexion test produced paresthesia at the thumb, index, and long fingers A positive percussion test at the wrist and a positive wrist flexion test produced paresthesias at the thumb, index, and long fingers. This statement is not true.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Clinical features of Median nerve compression Pain and paraesthesia occur in the distribution of the median nerve in the hand. Night after night the patient is woken with burning pain, tingling and numbness. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed, or shaking the arm, may relieve the symptoms. Sensory symptoms can often be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve ( Tinel's sign ) or By holding the wrist fully flexed for less than 60 seconds ( Phalen's test ). In late cases, there is wasting of the thenar muscles, weakness of thumb abduction and sensory dulling in the median nerve territory Option: A, B & D. In carpal tunnel syndrome, diminished two-point discrimination and dryness of the index and long fingers.

questions.text: Damage to the radial nerve in the spinal groove spares the?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Long head of triceps Branch to the long head of triceps is given more proximally , hence spared here.

Highyeild:

Radial nerve Course in the arm: In the arm, the radial nerve gives off the posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm and a branch to the medial head of the triceps. And travels infero-laterally into the groove for the radial nerve on the posterior surface of the humerus, winding spirally around the bone. In the groove, it gives branches to the lateral head of the triceps and anconeus muscles , and cutaneous branches to the arm and forearm.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Branch to the lateral head of the triceps is given at the groove. Option: C. Branch to Medial head of triceps is given in the arm. Option: D. Branch to Anconeus is given at the groove
